issues.description: The UML in the problem statement declares Ride's attributes with protected visibility (#name: String, #abbreviation: char), while the reference solution (and the typical expected student implementation) declare these attributes as private. The textual instructions require public getters but do not explicitly state the attribute visibility. This mismatch between the UML visibility marker and the actual/expected implementation can confuse students about whether they must make the attributes protected or private.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the visibility explicit and consistent: either change the UML attribute markers for Ride from protected (#) to private (-) to match the intended/solution implementation, or update the textual instructions to explicitly require protected attributes. Preferably update the UML to use '-' (private) or add a note in the problem statement that attributes should be private (students should still provide public getters).
